qas.question: What event in England during the 16th century had an outcome of many deaths for heresy?
During what king's reign did 60 Protestants die for heresy?
What two notable figures are cited to have perished for refusing to give up the Church in England?

answers.text: Sir Thomas More and Cardinal John Fisher

qas.question: Under which king were the heresy laws repealed in 1547?
In what year was the last known person sentenced to death in England for heresy?
What rformation took place in the 1600's
During who's reign were Catholics executed as heretics?
Who executed Protestants on political grounds?

plausible_answers.text: Sir Thomas More and Cardinal John Fisher

qas.question: What protestants were executed for not recognizing the kings supremecy?
Who repealed the heresey laws in the 15th century?

context: In England, the 16th-century <a0_0><b5_0>European Reformation<b5_0/><a0_0/> resulted in a number of executions on charges of heresy. During the thirty-eight years of <a1_0><b6_0><b7_0>Henry VIII<a1_0/>'s<b7_0/><b6_0/> reign, about sixty heretics, mainly Protestants, were executed and a rather greater number of Catholics lost their lives on grounds of political offences such as treason, notably <a2_0><b8_0>Sir Thomas More and Cardinal John Fisher<b8_0/><a2_0/>, for refusing to accept the king's supremacy over the Church in England. Under <a3_0><b9_0>Edward VI<b9_0/><a3_0/>, the heresy laws were repealed in 1547 only to be reintroduced in 1554 by Mary I; even so two radicals were executed in Edward's reign (one for denying the reality of the incarnation, the other for denying Christ's divinity). Under Mary, around two hundred and ninety people were burned at the stake between 1555 and 1558 after the restoration of papal jurisdiction. When Elizabeth I came to the throne, the concept of heresy was retained in theory but severely restricted by the 1559 Act of Supremacy and the one hundred and eighty or so Catholics who were executed in the forty-five years of her reign were put to death because they were considered members of "...a subversive fifth column." The last execution of a "heretic" in England occurred under James VI and I in <a4_0>1612<a4_0/>. Although the charge was technically one of "blasphemy" there was one later execution in Scotland (still at that date an entirely independent kingdom) when in 1697 Thomas Aikenhead was accused, among other things, of denying the doctrine of the Trinity.
